pyttn.utils package

Submodules

pyttn.utils.mode_combination module

class pyttn.utils.mode_combination.ModeCombination(nhilb=1, nbmax=1, blocksize=1)[source]

Bases: object

A class for automatically combining modes of a system_modes object together to form a new system_modes object consisting of composite modes. The approach implemented within this class involves sweeping from left to right and we attempt to combine the next mode into the current mode provided we have not already combined nbmax modes together in this mode and the local hilbert space dimension of the composite mode is less than nbmax.

Constructor arguments

Parameters:

  • nhilb (int, optional) – The maximum local Hilbert space dimension to allow during the mode combination process (default:1)

  • nbmax (int, optional) – The maximum number of modes to combine(default:1)

  • blocksize (int, optional) – An optional blocksize argument. For a blocksize of X, the current mode will contain a multiple of X modes and the new mode to add will contain X modes provided we have not reached the end of the chain(default:1)

Callable arguments :param system: the system_modes object defining all mode data :type mode_dims: system_modes :param blocksize: An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None) :type blocksize: int or None, optional :returns: The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode :rtype: list of list

__call__(system, _blocksize=None)[source]

Perform the mode combination process on a system_modes object.

Parameters:

  • system – the system_modes object defining all mode data

  • blocksize (int or None, optional) – An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None)

Returns:

The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode

Return type:

list of list

mode_combination_array(mode_dims, mode_inds=None, _blocksize=None)[source]

Perform the mode combination process on a array of mode dimensions.

Parameters:

  • mode_dims (list or np.ndarray) – the mode dimensions

  • mode_inds (list or np.ndarray, optional) – the index labels of each of the modes (defaults to None) in which case we assume the modes are labelled [x for x in range(len(mode_dims))]

  • blocksize (int or None, optional) – An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None)

Returns:

The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode

Return type:

list of list

mode_combination_system(system, _blocksize=None)[source]

Perform the mode combination process on a system_modes object.

Parameters:

  • system – the system_modes object defining all mode data

  • blocksize (int or None, optional) – An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None)

Returns:

The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode

Return type:

list of list

pyttn.utils.truncate module

class pyttn.utils.truncate.DepthTruncation(Lmax=2)[source]

Bases: TruncationBase

A class for truncating system modes to a fixed number of levels

Constructor arguments

Parameters:

Lmax (int, optional) – The number of states to include in the local Hilbert space (default:2)

Callable arguments

Parameters:

  • gk (np.ndarray) – The interaction strength

  • wk (np.ndarray) – The mode frequency

  • is_fermion (bool) – Whether or not the modes to be truncated are fermionic

Returns:

A list containing the local Hilbert space dimension of each mode

Return type:

list

__call__(gk, wk, is_fermion)[source]

Call self as a function.

class pyttn.utils.truncate.EnergyTruncation(ecut=0, Lmax=2, Lmin=1, func='abs')[source]

Bases: TruncationBase

A class for truncating system modes to a fixed number of levels

Constructor arguments

Parameters:

  • ecut (float, optional) – The maximum energy to include in the problem (defaul: 0)

  • Lmax (int, optional) – The maximum number of states to include in the local Hilbert space (default:2)

  • Lmin (int, optional) – The minimum number of states to include in the local Hilbert space (default:1)

  • func ({"abs", "real"}, optional) – Whether to use the absolute value or real part of the frequency. (default: “abs”)

Callable arguments

Parameters:

  • gk (np.ndarray) – The interaction strength

  • wk (np.ndarray) – The mode frequency

  • is_fermion (bool) – Whether or not the modes to be truncated are fermionic

Returns:

A list containing the local Hilbert space dimension of each mode

Return type:

list

pyttn.utils.visualise_tree module

pyttn.utils.visualise_tree.visualise_tree(tree, prog='dot', ax=None, node_size=500, linewidth=3, add_labels=True)[source]

A function for plotting an ntree object

Parameters:

  • tree (ntree) – The tree to be visualised

  • prog (Matplotlib Axes object, optional) – The visualisation function used with graphviz_layout (default: “dot”)

  • ax – Draw the tree in specified Matplotlib axes

  • node_size (int, optional) – The node size used for visualisation (default: 500)

  • linewidth (int, optional) – The width of edges connecting nodes (default: 3)

  • add_labels (bool, optional) – Whether or not to include the node labels (default: True)

class pyttn.utils.ModeCombination(nhilb=1, nbmax=1, blocksize=1)[source]

Bases: object

A class for automatically combining modes of a system_modes object together to form a new system_modes object consisting of composite modes. The approach implemented within this class involves sweeping from left to right and we attempt to combine the next mode into the current mode provided we have not already combined nbmax modes together in this mode and the local hilbert space dimension of the composite mode is less than nbmax.

Constructor arguments

Parameters:

  • nhilb (int, optional) – The maximum local Hilbert space dimension to allow during the mode combination process (default:1)

  • nbmax (int, optional) – The maximum number of modes to combine(default:1)

  • blocksize (int, optional) – An optional blocksize argument. For a blocksize of X, the current mode will contain a multiple of X modes and the new mode to add will contain X modes provided we have not reached the end of the chain(default:1)

Callable arguments :param system: the system_modes object defining all mode data :type mode_dims: system_modes :param blocksize: An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None) :type blocksize: int or None, optional :returns: The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode :rtype: list of list

__call__(system, _blocksize=None)[source]

Perform the mode combination process on a system_modes object.

Parameters:

  • system – the system_modes object defining all mode data

  • blocksize (int or None, optional) – An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None)

Returns:

The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode

Return type:

list of list

pyttn.utils.visualise_tree(tree, prog='dot', ax=None, node_size=500, linewidth=3, add_labels=True)[source]

A function for plotting an ntree object

Parameters:

  • tree (ntree) – The tree to be visualised

  • prog (Matplotlib Axes object, optional) – The visualisation function used with graphviz_layout (default: “dot”)

  • ax – Draw the tree in specified Matplotlib axes

  • node_size (int, optional) – The node size used for visualisation (default: 500)

  • linewidth (int, optional) – The width of edges connecting nodes (default: 3)

  • add_labels (bool, optional) – Whether or not to include the node labels (default: True)
